study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hengshun aromatic vinegar (HSAV) could protect against vascular endothelial injury (VEI) and elucidate its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: HSAV improved cell viability, reduced oxidative stress, and inhibited apoptosis in H2O2-induced human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and methionine-induced VEI in rats. It also modulated key biomarkers and signaling pathways, including PKCζ, Sirt1, and PIASy.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and methionine-induced VEI in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Hengshun aromatic vinegar (HSAV) on type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: HSAV improved glucose consumption and reduced triglycerides in metabolic disordered HepG2 cells, alleviated T2DM symptoms in rats, and regulated key pathways (PGC-1α/PGC-1β) involved in gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis.
population_specificity: Insulin-induced HepG2 cells and high-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced T2DM rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if vinegar processing reduces toxicity and enhances the anti-angiogenic effects of Curcuma phaeocaulis.
results_summary: Vinegar processing significantly reduced toxicity (higher LC50 values) and increased anti-angiogenic activity in zebrafish and rat models compared to raw materials. The volatile oil of vinegar-processed products inhibited blood vessel growth at 20 μg/mL, a concentration where raw materials showed no effect.
population_specificity: Zebrafish embryos (AB and FLk-GFP strains) and blood stasis syndrome rat models.
effective_dosage: Volatile oil: 20 μg/mL; Water decoction: LC50 values of 161.440 μg/mL (raw) and 206.239 μg/mL (vinegar-processed).

study_goal: The study does not address Vinegar; it focuses on COVID-19 vaccination policies for healthcare workers.
results_summary: The study does not examine Vinegar; it discusses coercive vaccination approaches for healthcare workers.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary wood vinegar supplementation on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and meat quality in grower-finisher pigs.
results_summary: Dietary wood vinegar significantly improved body weight gain, average daily gain, nutrient digestibility, and certain meat quality parameters (e.g., longissimus muscle area, yellowness, carcass weight), with no significant effects on lean meat percentage or backfat thickness.
population_specificity: Crossbred grower-finisher pigs (Landrace × Yorkshire × Duroc) with an initial average body weight of 30.48±4.23 kg.
effective_dosage: 0.05% and 0.1% wood vinegar supplementation in the basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemical profile and pharmacological mechanisms of the essential oil of Rhizoma curcumae (EORC), including vinegar-processed EORC, against liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that EORC, particularly when vinegar-processed, significantly alleviated liver fibrosis by regulating the TGF-β1/Smads and PI3K/AKT pathways, with vinegar-processed EORC showing more pronounced effects than raw EORC.
population_specificity: CCl4-induced liver fibrosis rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties of melanoidins from Chinese traditional vinegar powder in ethanol-induced macrophages and their potential therapeutic role in preventing alcohol-induced cell damage.
results_summary: Melanoidins significantly suppressed ethanol-induced proinflammatory cytokine expression and secretion, reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, and attenuated decreases in SIRT1, SIRT3, and NAD+ levels, suggesting protective effects against alcohol-induced inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of liquid vinegar versus commercial vinegar tablets in reducing postmeal glucose excursions in healthy adults.
results_summary: Liquid vinegar (VIN) significantly reduced the 60-minute glucose excursion by 31% compared to the control (CON) and whole vinegar tablets (PILL). Crushed tablets (PILL-c) showed a modest but non-significant reduction compared to CON.
population_specificity: Twelve young, healthy men and women (mean age 22.6 years, BMI 21.2 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 25 g liquid vinegar (1.25 g acetic acid) or four vinegar tablets (1.50 g acetic acid), taken once at mealtime.
study_duration: Single administration per treatment, with one-week washout between tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the health benefits of vinegar, particularly its role in metabolism and circulation, based on its bioactive constituents.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that vinegar is recognized for its health benefits, especially in metabolism and circulation, due to bioactive compounds like acetic acid and polyphenols. It is also valued in Islamic tradition as a beneficial condiment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to modern medicine and Islamic tradition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the treatment outcomes and side effects of 1% diluted vinegar ear drops versus 1% chloramphenicol ear drops for granular myringitis.
results_summary: 11 of 12 patients treated with 1% diluted vinegar had complete recovery, compared to 8 of 12 in the chloramphenicol group, though the difference was not statistically significant. Side effects of vinegar included dizziness and mild external auditory canal irritation.
population_specificity: 24 patients aged over 18 with granular myringitis grade I or II within 90 days of symptom onset.
effective_dosage: 1% diluted vinegar ear drops (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of apple vinegar as an irrigation agent in vital pulp therapy for irreversible pulpitis in adult permanent teeth.
results_summary: Apple vinegar showed marginally successful outcomes but significantly improved pain alleviation compared to ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid, with lower pain levels postoperatively. The success rate between the two groups was non-statistically significant after one year.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-50 with symptomatic irreversible pulpitis but no periapical radiolucency.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as an irrigation agent for five minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential anti-inflammatory effects of wood vinegar from Griffith's ash in LPS-activated macrophages.
results_summary: The wood vinegar inhibited the production of inflammatory markers (iNOS, NO, and interleukin 6) and reduced phosphorylation levels of p38 and protein kinase C-α/δ in LPS-stimulated macrophages, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages (a mouse macrophage cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various first-aid treatments, including vinegar, for marine animal envenomations.
results_summary: The abstract mentions vinegar as one of the treatments explored but does not provide specific findings regarding its efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Individuals affected by marine animal envenomations (e.g., jellyfish stings, stingray injuries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of apple vinegar as a nonantibiotic alternative for Staphylococcus aureus nasal decolonization.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that apple vinegar is experimentally proven to be efficacious in promoting S. aureus nasal decolonization, but no specific results or data are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential applications).

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal related to Vinegar.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Vinegar.
population_specificity: Not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of 1% and 2% acetic acid (vinegar) solutions in treating granular myringitis over a two-week period.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in treatment success rates between the 1% and 2% vinegar groups after two weeks, with a 10% recurrence rate observed eight weeks post-treatment. All patients tolerated the diluted vinegar well.
population_specificity: 47 participants with granular myringitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of vinegar, among other dietary interventions, on postprandial glycemia and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that vinegar, along with other alternative foods, may help ameliorate postprandial hyperglycemia and insulin resistance, but specific results or mechanisms are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of dietary interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of increased exposure to SCFAs, including those from apple cider vinegar, on colonic fermentation and adaptive immune cells in healthy humans.
results_summary: The high-SCFA diet, which included apple cider vinegar, significantly increased fecal and plasma SCFA concentrations and reduced certain immune cell populations compared to the low-SCFA diet.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults aged 18-45 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (provided as part of a high-SCFA diet including resistant starch, inulin, and apple cider vinegar).
study_duration: 21 days per diet with a 21-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of vinegar on glycemic control in both healthy individuals and those with impaired glucose tolerance or type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Vinegar intake acutely decreased glucose response in both healthy volunteers and individuals with impaired glucose tolerance or type 2 diabetes, though evidence was uncertain due to significant heterogeneity and risks of bias. Other SCFAs (acetate, propionate, butyrate) showed no significant effect on blood glucose or insulin.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers and individuals with impaired glucose tolerance or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify the study's goal regarding Vinegar.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Vinegar.
population_specificity: Not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the incidence and pattern of jellyfish stings in Malaysia and the use of vinegar as first aid.
results_summary: Vinegar was applied as first aid in 53.3% of reported stings, and all patients were treated symptomatically and discharged well. The study did not specifically evaluate vinegar's efficacy beyond its use as a first aid measure.
population_specificity: Young adults aged 10 to 29 years old who experienced jellyfish stings in Manjung, Perak, and Langkawi Island, Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of dietary acetic acid (vinegar) supplementation on metabolic and anthropometric outcomes in adults, particularly focusing on individuals with type 2 diabetes and those who are overweight or obese.
results_summary: The study found that acetic acid supplementation significantly reduced triacylglycerol (TAG) levels in overweight/obese individuals and fasting blood glucose (FBG) in those with type 2 diabetes, but no significant effects were observed on HbA1c, HDL, or anthropometric markers.
population_specificity: Adults, including individuals with type 2 diabetes and overweight/obese but otherwise healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: 750–3600 mg acetic acid daily (exact dose unspecified in 5 of 16 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of apple vinegar (AV) on metabolic parameters and body weight in humans and animals, as well as assess its safety and side effects.
results_summary: The study found potential beneficial health effects from AV consumption, with minimal side effects when ingested as recommended, but concluded that more high-quality research is needed for definitive evidence.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (mammals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of vinegar, among other Unani medicine drugs, in health protection and infection management during epidemics like COVID-19.
results_summary: The abstract mentions vinegar as one of the prescribed drugs in Unani medicine for health protection during epidemics, but it does not provide specific results on its effectiveness or mechanisms. Scientific research on these drugs suggests the presence of pharmacologically active substances that may offer insights into managing infections.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population during epidemics).

study_goal: The researchers were exploring the renewed interest in historic treatments like vinegar for palliative wound care, focusing on symptom management.
results_summary: The abstract mentions vinegar as a historic treatment gaining renewed interest but does not provide specific findings on its effects.
population_specificity: Patients and caregivers facing palliative wound care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and discuss the biological activities, phytochemistry, and toxicity of Euphorbia kansui before and after vinegar-processing, providing insights for further research.
results_summary: Vinegar-processing reduced the toxicity of Euphorbia kansui while retaining its diuretic and purgative effects, though the specific mechanism remains unclear. Some terpenoids showed reduced content, while new compounds were generated.
population_specificity: Mice, rats, and zebrafish embryos (preclinical models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health effects of apple vinegar on glycemic indices and oxidative stress in patients with type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia.
results_summary: Apple vinegar significantly improved fasting blood sugar (FBS) and antioxidant capacity (DPPH) compared to the control group, with no significant effects on blood pressure or homocysteine. Glycemic indices improved in both groups, but oxidative stress markers showed a notable difference favoring the vinegar group.
population_specificity: 70 participants with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of C. spinosa oxymel (a mixture containing grape vinegar) on blood glucose, lipid profile, and metabolic syndrome markers in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: C. spinosa oxymel prevented further increases in blood glucose and triglycerides but did not enhance the effects of hypoglycemic or hypolipidemic drugs. No significant adverse effects on kidney or liver function were observed.
population_specificity: Thirty diabetic patients with metabolic syndrome and poorly controlled glycemic status despite oral hypoglycemic therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of vinegar and other adjuvants in processing Chinese medicines to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that vinegar and other adjuvants can alter the content of active or toxic components in drugs, influence drug dissolution, and affect pharmacokinetics, thereby improving the therapeutic properties of traditional Chinese medicines.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of processing methods in traditional Chinese medicine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-biofilm activities of vinegar with water (1:1) against biofilms from methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and quinolone-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa in vitro.
results_summary: Vinegar with water (1:1) effectively inhibited biofilm formation from methicillin-resistant S. aureus and quinolone-resistant P. aeruginosa, demonstrating potent anti-biofilm activity. The study concluded that vinegar with water (1:1) provides safe pH levels for avoiding ototoxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro biofilms from methicillin-resistant S. aureus and quinolone-resistant P. aeruginosa.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the genetic factors contributing to alcohol use disorder (AUD) and its prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention any findings related to Vinegar.
population_specificity: Not specified (focuses on genetic and behavioral model organisms for AUD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize home skin care practices, including the use of dilute vinegar, in children with epidermolysis bullosa (EB) and identify patterns of antimicrobial resistance in EB wounds.
results_summary: Fewer than half of participants reported using dilute vinegar as part of their bathing routine. The study did not evaluate vinegar's specific effects on wound care outcomes or resistance patterns.
population_specificity: 23 children with epidermolysis bullosa (EB) at an outpatient pediatric dermatology practice in New York City.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review control trials to determine the effect of vinegar intake on postprandial glucose and insulin responses.
results_summary: The pooled analysis showed a significant reduction in postprandial glucose and insulin levels in participants who consumed vinegar compared to the control group, suggesting vinegar may improve glycemic control.
population_specificity: Not specified (participants in reviewed control trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vinegar (5% acetic acid) as a first aid measure for jellyfish stings, alongside other treatments like heat application or lidocaine.
results_summary: The study suggests that rinsing the sting site with vinegar (5% acetic acid) is substantiated by evidence as an effective first aid measure for jellyfish stings, though species-specific differences may apply. Controlled clinical trials or reliable models are needed to confirm efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Individuals affected by Scyphozoa (true jellyfish) stings.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed historical and current treatments for lice infestations, including vinegar, to assess their effectiveness and explore new strategies.
results_summary: Vinegar was mentioned as one of the older methods for lice control, but the abstract indicates that lice infestation cases and resistance have increased despite such treatments. No specific efficacy data for vinegar was provided.
population_specificity: Humans infested with lice (head, body, or pubic lice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vinegar (as an acidic food ingredient) on the frictional forces and surface deterioration of orthodontic brackets and wires.
results_summary: Vinegar exposure resulted in a static frictional force of 2.57 N, higher than the control group (artificial saliva) but lower than Pepsi®. Polycrystalline alumina brackets showed more surface deterioration and higher frictional forces than stainless steel brackets.
population_specificity: Orthodontic brackets and wires (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of advanced biotechnology in enhancing phytochemical diversity and elucidating treatment mechanisms in Chinese herbal medicine, including traditional applications like vinegar production.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that biotechnology can increase phytochemical diversity, elucidate treatment mechanisms, and accelerate drug discovery in Chinese herbal medicine, but does not provide specific findings about vinegar's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the traditional and modern medical applications of Ma'aljobon (a vinegar-derived substance) for treating skin disorders.
results_summary: Traditional Persian medicine sources indicated Ma'aljobon as a safe and effective remedy for skin diseases like pimples and ulcers, while modern evidence supported whey protein's effectiveness in conditions like atopic dermatitis. Gastrointestinal discomfort was the only noted adverse effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of traditional sources and modern literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dousing areas of contact with vinegar could relieve symptoms of Irukandji syndrome.
results_summary: The review found a lack of evidence for vinegar's effectiveness in relieving Irukandji syndrome symptoms, recommending adherence to local guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with Irukandji syndrome (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chemical profiles of raw and vinegar-processed Gansui to understand how vinegar processing reduces toxicity.
results_summary: Vinegar processing significantly reduced the levels of 11 toxic terpenoids in Gansui, with reductions ranging from 6.66% to 95.25%, supporting its role in toxicity reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro chemical analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial activities of various antiseptic solutions, including vinegar diluted with water (1:1), against antibiotic-resistant and susceptible bacterial strains in vitro.
results_summary: Vinegar with water (1:1) demonstrated moderate antimicrobial activity against MRSA, MSSA, QRPA, and QSPA, ranking below Burow's solution and 2% acetic acid but above 4% boric acid solution. The study found that Burow's solution was the most effective, but vinegar still showed measurable efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial strains (MRSA, MSSA, QRPA, QSPA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate vinegar's effectiveness in modulating glycemic control and its underlying molecular mechanisms, particularly comparing its effects in normal glucose-tolerant individuals versus those with type 2 diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance.
results_summary: Vinegar consumption was more effective in improving glycemic control in normal glucose-tolerant individuals than in diabetics or those with impaired glucose tolerance. Mechanisms included activation of FFAR2 receptors, increased AMPK activation, reduced free fatty acids, improved blood flow, and increased satiety.
population_specificity: Normal glucose-tolerant individuals, type 2 diabetics, and those with impaired glucose tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinegar could relieve symptoms of Irukandji syndrome.
results_summary: The study found a lack of evidence for vinegar's effectiveness in treating Irukandji syndrome, recommending adherence to local guidelines instead.
population_specificity: Patients with Irukandji syndrome (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diluted vinegar against Avena sativa and hydroxyzine in reducing uremic pruritus in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Vinegar significantly decreased all measured pruritus scores (intensity, consequences, frequency, and pruritic surface), demonstrating effectiveness comparable to hydroxyzine and superior to Avena sativa in some aspects.
population_specificity: 23 hemodialysis patients with uremic pruritus.
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention, with a 3-day washout period between crossovers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess vinegar's efficacy as an antifungal agent for inhibiting the growth of common indoor fungi (Aspergillus fumigatus and Penicillium chrysogenum).
results_summary: Vinegar (4.0%-4.2% acetic acid) inhibited the growth of P. chrysogenum but not A. fumigatus, and it also showed notable inhibition of sporulation.
population_specificity: Fungi isolated from indoor air samples (A. fumigatus and P. chrysogenum).
effective_dosage: 4.0%-4.2% acetic acid (concentration used, exact application method not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of vinegar on glucose and lipid metabolism, evaluating its potential benefits for conditions like hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and obesity.
results_summary: Some studies showed vinegar reduced hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, hyperlipidemia, and obesity, while others found no metabolic benefits. Proposed mechanisms include delayed gastric emptying, improved glucose utilization, and increased lipolysis, but large-scale trials are needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with glucose and lipid abnormalities (general population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinegar could serve as a modest AMPK activator, potentially mimicking some health-protective effects of calorie restriction.
results_summary: The study suggests that regular vinegar ingestion may achieve a modest degree of AMPK activation, which could contribute to health benefits similar to those of metformin and berberine, though with less efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history, production, varieties, and functional properties of vinegar, focusing on its bioactive components and associated health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that vinegar contains multiple bioactive compounds (e.g., acetic acid, polyphenols) linked to antioxidative, antidiabetic, antimicrobial, antitumor, antiobesity, antihypertensive, and cholesterol-lowering effects. However, the abstract does not provide specific quantitative outcomes or clinical trial data.
population_specificity: General human populations (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dietary components, including vinegar, on blood glucose modulation in the context of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) prevention and management.
results_summary: The review suggests that dietary components, including vinegar, have significant and clinically relevant effects on blood glucose regulation, supporting their role in T2DM management.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on individuals at risk or diagnosed with T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ingesting pickle juice (PJ) or mustard while hypohydrated affects plasma sodium, potassium, osmolality, or changes in plasma volume or sodium content.
results_summary: Ingesting PJ or mustard after dehydration did not exacerbate exercise-induced hypertonicity or cause hyperkalemia, but it also did not fully replenish electrolytes or fluid losses. No significant changes in plasma sodium, potassium, or osmolality were observed within 60 minutes of ingestion.
population_specificity: 9 physically active, nonacclimated individuals (age 25 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: 1 mL/kg body mass of PJ or deionized water; mustard mass containing similar sodium content as PJ.
study_duration: Blood samples collected up to 60 minutes post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinegar could improve metabolic and hormonal indices and restore ovulatory function in PCOS patients by enhancing insulin sensitivity.
results_summary: Intake of vinegar reduced insulin resistance (HOMA-R) in six of seven patients, lowered the LH/FSH ratio in five patients, and restored ovulatory menstruation within 40 days in four patients. The findings suggest vinegar may improve insulin sensitivity and ovulatory function in PCOS.
population_specificity: Seven patients with PCOS seeking non-pharmacological treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if vinegar's palatability and tolerability influence its role in suppressing appetite and food intake, and whether its effects are due to nausea rather than genuine satiety.
results_summary: Vinegar ingestion reduced appetite measures but increased nausea, with unpalatable treatments having the strongest effect. Orosensory stimulation alone did not influence appetite, suggesting vinegar's satiety effects are linked to poor tolerability and nausea.
population_specificity: Healthy, young, normal-weight, unrestrained eaters (Study 1: n=16; Study 2: n=14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vinegar as a treatment for jellyfish envenomation, specifically its impact on pain exacerbation and nematocyst discharge.
results_summary: The study found that vinegar often exacerbates pain or triggers nematocyst discharge in most jellyfish species, making it generally ineffective or harmful. However, vinegar may be beneficial for envenomation by the bluebottle (Physalia).
population_specificity: Individuals envenomed by jellyfish (cnidarian) and related organisms in North America and Hawaii.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of buffered vinegar (VIN) in beef enhancement solutions on meat quality, shelf-life, and palatability compared to other treatments.
results_summary: VIN-enhanced beef was subjectively redder than other treatments on day 7 of retail display but scored lower for sensory tenderness. No difference in shear force was observed between treatments.
population_specificity: Top sirloin beef cuts.
effective_dosage: 2% buffered vinegar in the final product.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of acetate from vinegar capsules and vinegar drinks in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The vinegar drink group showed a rapid increase in serum acetate, peaking at 15 minutes, while the capsule group peaked at 30 minutes. Both forms achieved physiologically active concentrations, with no significant difference in total absorbed acetate between them.
population_specificity: 30 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 750 mg acetic acid (9 vinegar capsules or 100 mL vinegar drink)
study_duration: Single administration with blood sampling over 180 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the cleaning recommendations for removable orthodontic appliances (ROAs) in Germany, including the use of diluted vinegar, and compare them with published procedures.
results_summary: The study found that 30.5% of orthodontists recommended treatment with diluted vinegar or citric acid for cleaning ROAs, though mechanical cleaning was the most common method. The use of cleaning solutions, including vinegar, was comparatively infrequent despite literature suggesting their hygienic benefits.
population_specificity: Orthodontists in Germany (450 randomly selected).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could mitigate locomotor hyperactivity in mice exposed to lead during early development by enhancing cAMP and cGMP signaling pathways.
results_summary: Lead-exposed female mice showed significant hyperactivity, which was reversed by vinpocetine treatment. No effect was observed in lead-exposed males.
population_specificity: Swiss mice exposed to lead during gestation and early postnatal development.
study_duration: Single dose administered 4 hours before evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rice vinegar administered via nasogastric tube could reduce catheter-associated bacteriuria and symptomatic UTIs in patients with long-term urinary catheterization.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in urinary pH, bacterial titer, and turbidity between the vinegar and control groups, with no symptomatic UTIs in the vinegar group compared to three in the control group. Rice vinegar may reduce bacteriuria and UTI risk, but longer-term and larger studies are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic urinary catheters from a long-term care facility in northern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: 100 ml of diluted rice vinegar daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vinpocetine, alone or with Lactobacillus, could counteract neurodegeneration pathways and improve motor function in a rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease rat model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly improved motor function, increased dopamine synthesis, reduced oxidative stress and neuroinflammation, and decreased proteinopathies (α-synuclein and tau) in the brain.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats with rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel intranasal mucoadhesive in-situ gel of vinpocetine for targeting the brain in Alzheimer's disease treatment.
results_summary: The intranasal gel showed improved drug release, enhanced brain targeting (2-fold increase in Cmax and AUC0-t), and significantly greater efficacy in alleviating AD symptoms compared to oral administration in a rat model.
population_specificity: Rat model of Alzheimer's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Vinpocetine's role in suppressing ferroptosis and extracellular matrix degradation in osteoarthritis, as well as its underlying mechanisms via the Nrf2/GPX4 pathway.
results_summary: Vinpocetine effectively suppressed TBHP-induced ferroptosis and ECM degradation, improved mitochondrial function, and slowed OA progression in mice by activating the Nrf2/GPX4 pathway and inhibiting Keap1-Nrf2 interaction.
population_specificity: OA mouse model and TBHP-induced chondrocyte injury in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Vinpocetine's protective and remodeling effects in diabetic cardiomyopathy by evaluating biochemical and histopathological parameters.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced cardiac muscle thickness, TGF-β1 expression, and plasma markers in diabetic rats, while increasing HIF-1 alpha and neuregulin-1β levels. Histopathological observations confirmed reduced fibrosis and structural abnormalities in Vinpocetine-treated hearts.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with streptozocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanistic role of Vinpocetine in atherosclerosis, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and plaque-stabilizing effects.
results_summary: Vinpocetine was found to inhibit atherosclerosis formation by reducing oxidative stress, blocking pro-inflammatory cytokines, and promoting plaque stability through NF-κB and PDE1 inhibition. It also prevented monocyte adhesion and migration, contributing to endothelial dysfunction management.
population_specificity: Not specified (general endothelial dysfunction and atherosclerosis context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of Vinpocetine (VPN) at varying doses (5 mg/kg or 10 mg/kg) after cold-induced traumatic brain injury (TBI) in mice.
results_summary: VPN administration significantly reduced brain infarct volume, swelling, blood-brain barrier disruption, and DNA fragmentation in a dose-dependent manner. Long-term VPN treatment improved locomotor activity, cell proliferation, neurogenesis, and decreased whole brain atrophy, particularly in the motor cortex.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice subjected to cold-induced TBI.
study_duration: Initiated 48 hours post-TBI, with outcomes assessed at 2 or 28 days post-TBI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could alleviate abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) by reducing vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) senescence via the SIRT1-dependent pathway.
results_summary: Vinpocetine pre-treatment prevented aneurysmal dilation, reduced aortic rupture, and decreased elastin degradation, MMP activity, macrophage infiltration, ROS production, collagen remodeling, and VSMC senescence in elastase-induced AAA mice. These effects were dependent on SIRT1, as they were absent in VSMC-specific SIRT1 knockout mice.
population_specificity: Elastase-induced AAA mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic impact of vinpocetine, alone or combined with Lactobacillus, on hepatic abnormalities caused by a high-fat diet and diabetes in rats.
results_summary: Vinpocetine dose-dependently reduced liver injury markers, fibrosis, oxidative stress, and inflammation, while restoring antioxidant parameters. Combining vinpocetine with Lactobacillus further improved inflammation, oxidative stress, insulin resistance, and lipid profile abnormalities.
population_specificity: Rats with high-fat diet-induced hepatic abnormalities and diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vinpocetine on a DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis (AD)-like model in mice, focusing on its potential to improve AD symptoms and skin barrier function.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved eczema severity, skin barrier function, and reduced inflammatory markers (IgE, IL-6, IL-13) and cellular infiltration in the AD model. It also lowered mRNA levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and TGF-β protein in skin tissue.
population_specificity: Mice with DNCB-induced AD-like symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vinpocetine alone or in combination with albendazole reduces the spore load of Encephalitozoon intestinalis in infected HEK293 cells.
results_summary: Vinpocetine alone did not significantly reduce spore DNA load, but it enhanced the effect of albendazole when used in combination. The study found no significant difference from the control with vinpocetine alone at 4-20 µM.
population_specificity: HEK293 cells infected with Encephalitozoon intestinalis.
interactions: Enhanced effect when combined with albendazole.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the synthesis and activity studies of Vinpocetine and its derivatives to guide the development of more potent derivatives.
results_summary: Vinpocetine and its derivatives showed potential in treating ischemic stroke, neuroprotection, anti-inflammatory effects, anti-aging, insomnia, and depression, but faced limitations like low bioavailability and hepatic first-pass effects. The study reviewed five primary methodologies for synthesizing derivatives to address these issues.
population_specificity: Not specified (general research context, not clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop chitosan nanoparticles loaded with Vinpocetine to enhance brain delivery via intranasal administration, overcoming low oral bioavailability.
results_summary: The optimized nanoparticles showed high entrapment efficiency and drug loading, with nasal administration nearly doubling brain exposure (Cmax and AUC0-t) compared to oral administration, while demonstrating no nasal mucosa irritation or toxicity.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vinpocetine on clinical manifestations of chronic cerebral ischemia (CCI) and its impact on neuroinflammation markers (S100B, IL-1β).
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly improved cognitive status, emotional state, daytime sleep parameters, and reduced asthenia in CCI patients. It also lowered S100B and IL-1β levels, suggesting a potential mechanism of neuroinflammation inhibition.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic cerebral ischemia (mean age 61.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Vinpocetine on dyskinesia in a 6-OHDA-induced Parkinson's disease rat model, focusing on motor function, oxidative stress, and the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved motor function, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA), increased antioxidant activity (SOD), downregulated α-synuclein expression, and activated the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway in PD rats.
population_specificity: 6-OHDA-induced Parkinson's disease rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of long-term topical Vinpocetine (VNP), alone and combined with clobetasol propionate, in a mouse model of psoriasiform dermatitis.
results_summary: Topical VNP reduced the severity of psoriatic lesions, reversed histopathological abnormalities, and significantly lowered inflammatory biomarkers like TNF-α, IL-17A, and NF-κB. The combination of VNP and clobetasol showed enhanced therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Swiss albino mice with imiquimod-induced psoriasiform dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 1% VNP, 3% VNP, and 3% VNP plus 0.05% clobetasol propionate, administered topically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of Vinpocetine in treating nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) by examining its effects on inflammasome activation and liver symptoms.
results_summary: Vinpocetine ameliorated hepatic steatosis and fibrosis, reduced liver enzyme levels, and suppressed inflammasome components in both mouse and cell models without causing observable side effects.
population_specificity: Mice fed a choline-deficient diet and primary hepatocytes/Kupffer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could improve seizure control and cognitive function in a patient with GABRG2-related drug-resistant epilepsy.
results_summary: The patient showed a dramatic initial response to vinpocetine, with further reduction in seizures and improvement in cognitive functions. The study suggests vinpocetine may be beneficial for GABRG2-related drug-resistant epilepsy.
population_specificity: An 8-year-old boy with GABRG2-related drug-resistant epilepsy and a history of early onset absence epilepsy and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could improve epilepsy-associated behavioral issues and seizure control in a patient with a loss-of-function GABAA receptor gene variant.
results_summary: The patient experienced seizure freedom and an improved quality of life after 16 months of vinpocetine treatment, suggesting its potential efficacy in attenuating epilepsy-related symptoms in individuals with specific genetic variants.
population_specificity: A single patient diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, psychiatric complications, and therapy-resistant focal epilepsy due to a GABRA1 variant (p.(Arg112Gln)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate vinpocetine's potential protective effect against chloroquine (CQ) and hydroxychloroquine (HCQ)-induced cardiotoxicity in a mouse model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine co-treatment prevented CQ/HCQ-induced lethality, reduced cardiotoxicity biomarkers, and restored heart tissue morphology and antioxidant defenses. The study suggests vinpocetine could serve as an adjuvant therapy with CQ/HCQ.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic mechanism of Vinpocetine, particularly its effect on NLRP3 inflammasome, and its efficacy in alleviating ischemia-reperfusion injury in a mouse model of ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced infarct volume, improved behavioral function, inhibited neuronal apoptosis, and suppressed NLRP3 inflammasome expression, with maximal effects observed at 10 mg/kg/d. Its effects were comparable to MCC950, a specific NLRP3 inhibitor.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (tMCAO) to simulate ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of vinpocetine on rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease in rats, focusing on anti-neuroinflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reversed rotenone-induced motor deficits, cognitive impairments, gut dysfunction, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation, while also attenuating dopamine neuron loss and abnormal protein expressions.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of vinpocetine in preventing DMH-induced colon carcinogenesis and assess its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: Vinpocetine attenuated altered plasma parameters, improved lipid profiles, and demonstrated anti-proliferative effects by suppressing COX-2 stimulation and reducing levels of inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IL-10). It showed significant potential in preventing colorectal cancer.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats with DMH-induced pre-neoplastic colon damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective and therapeutic effects of Vinpocetine on hippocampal synaptic plasticity in a rat model of Alzheimer's disease induced by beta-amyloid.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly prevented the negative effects of beta-amyloid on long-term potentiation (LTP), demonstrating neuroprotective benefits when administered both before and after disease induction.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats
study_duration: 30 days (pretreatment or treatment) or 60 days (pretreatment + treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could improve metabolic syndrome-associated bladder overactivity by restoring succinate-modulated cAMP production and exerting anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved bladder overactivity, restored detrusor muscle responses, reduced inflammation, and modulated GPR91 downstream messengers. It also restored forskolin-induced cAMP production in the detrusor muscle.
population_specificity: Fructose-fed rats (a model of metabolic syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the components in vinpocetine injections that may cause allergic reactions and assess their potential sensitization effects.
results_summary: The study found that vinpocetine, vincamine, and impurity C bind to MRGPRX2, with impurity C causing mast cell degranulation, histamine release, and local sensitization in mice, suggesting it as a potential anaphylactoid component in vinpocetine injections.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and MRGPRX2-HEK293 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vinpocetine on diabetic cardiomyopathy in rats, focusing on its potential to improve cardiac function and reduce pathological markers.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved cardiac function, reduced glucose levels, oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis, and modulated key molecular pathways (PDE-1, TGF-β, p-Smad 2/3). Its effects were comparable to or synergistic with enalapril.
population_specificity: Rats with induced diabetic cardiomyopathy (high-fat diet + streptozotocin).
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated (study lasted 9 weeks total, with induction after 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of vinpocetine in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and its potential to enhance cisplatin sensitivity by suppressing Nrf2 signaling.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited NSCLC cell proliferation, promoted cisplatin-induced apoptosis, and suppressed Nrf2 signaling. In vivo, vinpocetine (50 mg/kg) reduced tumor growth and enhanced cisplatin's antitumor effects.
population_specificity: A549 cisplatin-resistant NSCLC cells (A549/DDP) and Nrf2-overexpressing cell lines, plus an NSCLC tumor-bearing mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect and mechanism of vinpocetine (VIN) and coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) combination on cognitive impairment induced by ionizing radiation (IR) in mice.
results_summary: VIN or CoQ10 alone mitigated cognitive dysfunction, neuron loss, mitochondrial damage, and oxidative stress injury, while enhancing mitophagy in hippocampal neurons. The combination of VIN and CoQ10 provided further protection against IR-induced cognitive dysfunction compared to either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Mice with cognitive impairment induced by 9-Gy ionizing radiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of vinpocetine on atopic dermatitis (AD) in mice, comparing its efficacy across oral, intraperitoneal, and topical administration routes.
results_summary: Vinpocetine suppressed serum IgE and IgG1 levels, reduced IL-4 and IL-13 production, decreased inflammatory cell invasion, and improved skin structure. Topical application was the most effective route.
population_specificity: HR-1 hairless mice with induced atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg (oral), 10 mg/kg (intraperitoneal), and 2 mg/kg (topical), administered twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness and tolerability of Vinpocetine in treating long-COVID symptoms in patients with chronic cerebrovascular disease.
results_summary: Vinpocetine showed significant improvement in functional status (PCFS) after 1 month of therapy and was well-tolerated without significant side effects. The most pronounced clinical effect was observed in functional status, with 59.5% of patients reporting pronounced improvement in well-being (GROC).
population_specificity: 97 patients (64.5±5.2 years) with chronic cerebrovascular disease, including 42 diagnosed with long-COVID.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential protective effects of vinpocetine against renal ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI) in rats and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced markers of kidney damage (serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen), oxidative stress (NADPH oxidase, malondialdehyde), inflammation (IKKβ, NF-κB p65, TNF-α, IL-6, myeloperoxidase), and apoptosis (cleaved caspase-3), while enhancing antioxidant defenses (Nrf2, reduced glutathione). Histopathological improvements confirmed its nephroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Male rats subjected to renal ischemia/reperfusion injury.

study_goal: The researchers investigated the mechanistic effect of oxidative stress (including Vitamin E analog Trolox) on red-light-mediated vasodilation in murine arteries and endothelial cells.
results_summary: Treatment with Trolox (a Vitamin E analog) decreased vessel dilation, suggesting that antioxidants may interfere with red-light-induced vasodilation. The study found that mild oxidative stress facilitates the traffic of vasodilatory substances, while antioxidants disfavor this mechanism.
population_specificity: Murine arteries and endothelial cells (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of vitamin E as a therapeutic agent for alleviating symptoms of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) in adolescents using computational methods.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin E has diverse potential in alleviating PCOS symptoms, with observed hormonal influences aligning with existing PCOS theories. Computational analysis supported its therapeutic promise for PCOS.
population_specificity: Adolescents with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding vitamins E and C improves the cryotolerance and viability of preantral follicles in ovine ovarian tissue during vitrification.
results_summary: The study found that vitamins E and C, especially when combined, increased intact preantral follicles, stromal cell density, antioxidant activity, and gene expression related to follicle development compared to the control group. Vitamin E showed stronger antioxidant effects, which were enhanced by vitamin C.
population_specificity: Ovine ovarian tissue from juvenile lambs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between serum vitamin E levels and the risk of bacterial vaginitis (BV) across different BMIs and ages.
results_summary: Higher serum vitamin E levels (1198-5459ug/dL) were negatively correlated with BV risk, showing significant reduction (p < 0.001). At lower levels, no significant association was found, and at high BMI levels, BV risk initially decreased then increased with rising vitamin E concentrations.
population_specificity: 2242 American participants from NHANES 1999-2006 cycles.
effective_dosage: Serum vitamin E levels categorized into four groups (specific dosages not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin E δ-tocotrienol (DT3) and aspirin on Wnt signaling in colon cancer stem cells and adenoma prevention in APCmin/+ mice.
results_summary: The combination of DT3 and aspirin inhibited cell growth, induced apoptosis in colon cancer stem cells, and reduced adenoma formation in mice by suppressing Wnt/β-catenin signaling. DT3 alone or with aspirin also decreased expression of β-catenin and its downstream targets.
population_specificity: Human colon cancer stem cells (CCSCs) and APCmin/+ mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic Vitamin E administration could improve bone mineral metabolism in epileptic rats undergoing swimming exercise.
results_summary: Vitamin E significantly increased bone calcium, magnesium, and zinc levels in epileptic rats that exercised, compared to epileptic rats without Vitamin E. However, it did not address chromium deficiency observed in all epileptic groups.
population_specificity: Epileptic rats induced with penicillin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vitamin E could protect against methotrexate-induced liver damage in rats.
results_summary: Vitamin E significantly reduced histopathological liver damage and lowered the apoptotic index in rats treated with methotrexate, demonstrating protective effects against hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between oxidative stress in neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and the effects of additional vitamin E supplementation during phototherapy.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation significantly reduced serum bilirubin levels in neonates by the third day of admission compared to the control group. It also increased total antioxidant capacity in preterm neonates and decreased the duration of phototherapy in full-term neonates.
population_specificity: Neonates with indirect hyperbilirubinemia admitted to NICUs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin E, alone and in combination with evening primrose oil, in alleviating breast pain associated with cyclical mastalgia.
results_summary: Vitamin E alone significantly reduced breast pain severity compared to placebo, with a mean reduction of 2.5 points on the pain scale. The combination of vitamin E and evening primrose oil showed superior efficacy, reducing pain by 4.5 points.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women with cyclical mastalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of combining carbimazole (CBZ) with vitamin E (VE) on testicular injury induced by experimental hyperthyroidism in rats, focusing on oxidative, inflammatory, and apoptotic pathways.
results_summary: The study found that adding vitamin E to carbimazole treatment reduced testicular side effects and improved spermatogenesis in hyperthyroid rats, with significant differences in oxidative stress and inflammatory markers. Group VIII (levothyroxine + CBZ + VE) showed the most improvement compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Adult male albino Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of biogenic selenium (Se) supplementation, including its interaction with Vitamin E (VE), on yolk lipid oxidation, cholesterol, fatty acids, and VE levels in laying hens.
results_summary: The study found that organic Se-supplemented groups (Se-yeast and VADS18) had significantly higher VE content in egg yolks compared to inorganic and control groups. The control group, which included a basal diet with 100 mg/kg VE, showed higher saturated fatty acid (SFA) contents than VE and Se-supplemented groups.
population_specificity: Lohmann Brown laying hens aged 50 weeks, weighing 1500–2000 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential roles of Vitamin E in preventing and treating bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis by assessing physiological, anatomical, and molecular markers.
results_summary: Vitamin E administration improved lung structure and function, reduced TGF-β levels, and inhibited the α-SMA/collagen I profibrotic pathway, suggesting its efficacy in ameliorating lung fibrosis.
population_specificity: Bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a water-soluble Vitamin E conjugate (TPGS) could reverse fluorescence quenching caused by sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) in polymicrobial biofilms on dentine.
results_summary: TPGS treatment led to faster recovery of bacterial fluorescence readings compared to the control after NaOCl exposure, suggesting partial reversal of quenching effects. The study concluded that TPGS may clinically reduce the time needed for fluorescence recovery when NaOCl is used as an irrigant.
population_specificity: Extracted human teeth with polymicrobial biofilms grown on dentine sections.
effective_dosage: Not specified (TPGS was applied post-NaOCl exposure, but exact concentration not detailed).
study_duration: Fluorescence readings were assessed over 10 minutes post-TPGS treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin E supplementation could restore testicular function and improve sperm cryo-resistance in aged mice.
results_summary: Higher dosages of vitamin E (200 and 400 mg/kg) improved sperm count, motility, morphology, and cryo-resistance, while also enhancing antioxidant capacity and gene expression related to testicular function. Chromatin abnormalities post-vitrification were reduced in treated groups.
population_specificity: 48-week-old male Naval Medical Research Institute mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of Vitamin E alone, saroglitazar alone, and their combination in treating NAFLD/NASH.
results_summary: Vitamin E alone significantly reduced alanine aminotransferase levels and showed modest improvements in liver stiffness and lipid parameters, though combination therapy with saroglitazar demonstrated more comprehensive benefits.
population_specificity: 175 NAFLD patients, mean age 45 ± 11 years, mean BMI 26 ± 3.6 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vitamin E mitigates the oxidative stress and immune suppression caused by non-esterified fatty acids (NEFAs) in bovine peripheral blood leukocytes (PBLs).
results_summary: The study found that vitamin E reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA) and restored some proinflammatory gene expression altered by NEFAs in bovine PBLs, though it did not affect phagocytosis in PMNs.
population_specificity: Transition-period cows (bovine peripheral blood leukocytes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential mechanisms of Vitamin E in preventing and treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and analyze its effects on oxidative damage, immunity, intestinal barrier integrity, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin E has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, improves oxidative damage, enhances immunity, maintains intestinal barrier integrity, suppresses inflammatory cytokines, and modulates gut microbiota, contributing to IBD prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pentoxifylline and vitamin E could mitigate radiation-induced renal fibrosis and damage in rats.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of pentoxifylline and vitamin E significantly mitigated radiation-induced kidney fibrosis, as evidenced by histomorphological, immunohistochemical, and TUNEL analyses, though no significant differences were observed in serum creatinine levels or body weight.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary Vitamin E supplementation could counteract the negative effects of increased nest temperature on nestling bird growth and survival.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation weakly increased nestling mass in heated nests but had the opposite effect in control nests. The effects were not strong, suggesting limited efficacy under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Nestling birds (species not specified) exposed to experimentally increased nest temperatures during incubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous vitamin E (VE) could enhance the tolerance of black soldier fly larvae to cadmium (Cd) exposure by reducing oxidative damage and Cd toxicity.
results_summary: Pretreatment with exogenous VE (100 mg/kg) increased larval body weight, reduced Cd content and toxicity, and mitigated oxidative damage by enhancing metallothionein content and antioxidant power, even at high Cd exposure levels (300–700 mg/kg).
population_specificity: Black soldier fly (Hermetia illucens) larvae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc and/or vitamin E could mitigate male reproductive toxicity caused by a mixture of phthalates (MPEs).
results_summary: Vitamin E, alone or combined with zinc, restored reproductive parameters (organ weights, hormone levels, sperm quality) and upregulated key proteins (PIWIL1, PIWIL2, StAR, CYP11A1, CYP19A1) that were negatively affected by MPEs.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a nanoformulated Berberine (Brb) with Vitamin E (TPGS) to mitigate doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by enhancing mitochondrial protection.
results_summary: The study found that cationic OA/TPGS mMic significantly enhanced Brb's mitochondrial protective effects, suppressed apoptosis, and improved cell viability under doxorubicin challenge, mediated by reduced caspase-9 and elevated Bcl-2 levels.
population_specificity: Cardiovascular muscle cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Sub-lethal doses of Brb via cationic OA/TPGS mMic; doxorubicin challenge up to ~50 µM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zinc and vitamin E supplementation on copper and zinc biomarkers in patients undergoing CABG surgery.
results_summary: The study found that plasma copper levels were transiently lower in the zinc-vitamin E group early after surgery, but other copper biomarkers remained unchanged. Vitamin E supplementation did not significantly affect ceruloplasmin, SOD activity, or ATOX1 expression, but MT2A expression was increased.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
effective_dosage: 1200 international units of vitamin E 1 day before surgery, followed by 200 units per day until 21 days after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on the role of vitamin E in delaying ageing and age-related diseases by examining its effects on the gut microbiome.
results_summary: Vitamin E positively influences the gut microbiome by increasing beneficial bacteria and metabolites, which may help delay ageing and reduce age-related diseases. However, more research is needed to fully understand these relationships.
population_specificity: Ageing individuals (not further specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of vitamin E supplementation alone or combined with other antioxidants on the incidence of stroke.
results_summary: Vitamin E alone did not reduce the incidence of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. When combined with other antioxidants, it reduced ischemic stroke but increased hemorrhagic stroke, negating any overall benefit.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 16 randomized controlled trials).
interactions: Other antioxidants (mentioned as interacting with vitamin E).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin E supplementation affects oxidative stress, inflammatory response, muscle damage, soreness, and strength in healthy adults after exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of vitamin E supplementation on lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, SOD activity, interleukin-6 levels, creatine kinase, muscle soreness, or muscle strength compared to placebo. The authors concluded that vitamin E should not be recommended for post-exercise recovery in healthy individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy adults after a bout of physical exercise
study_duration: Effects assessed between 0 h and 96 h after exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative supplementation of vitamin E and zinc could improve short-term postoperative outcomes in CABG surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin E and zinc supplementation significantly reduced hospital length of stay and lowered inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein, pentraxin 3, interferon γ, malondialdehyde, and aspartate aminotransferase) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing CABG surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.
effective_dosage: 1200 IU vitamin E preoperatively, followed by 200 IU daily postoperatively from day 2 to 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating whether the addition of Vitamin E to triplet chemotherapy (FOLFOXIRI) improves outcomes in metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that the median time to first hospitalization or death was not reached in the Vitamin E group, while it was 3.7 months in the placebo group, suggesting a potential benefit. However, the abstract does not provide conclusive efficacy or safety data for Vitamin E.
population_specificity: Seventy patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize scientific evidence on the effects of vitamin E supplementation on neuroprotection and neurodegeneration markers in experimental models.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation improved memory, cognition, learning, motor function, and brain markers linked to neuroregeneration and neuroprotection. It also reduced beta-amyloid deposition, tau-protein hyperphosphorylation, and increased superoxide dismutase and BDNF levels in rodents.
population_specificity: Experimental models (rodents) of neurodegenerative diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between vitamin E status and cardiovascular disease (CVD) and assess whether vitamin E deficiency (VED) coexists with CVD.
results_summary: The study found that low vitamin E concentrations are associated with increased CVD risk, but α-tocopherol supplementation alone did not show cardioprotective effects. It suggests that consuming all vitamin E isomers from food may be more beneficial than isolated supplementation.
population_specificity: Global populations, with higher VED prevalence noted in Asia and Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms of action of vitamin E and assess whether supplementation could be beneficial in non-communicable diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights vitamin E's potential benefits, including cellular protection through antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity, and improving lipid metabolism, but notes that data on its efficacy remains inconclusive.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of non-communicable diseases).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether Vitamin E supplementation contributed to transient hyperphosphatasemia in an adult transplant recipient.
results_summary: The study found that discontinuing Vitamin E, along with other nonessential medications, coincided with a decline in elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity, suggesting a possible association. However, no direct causal link was established.
population_specificity: A 54-year-old male with a history of multiple organ transplants (bilateral lung, liver, and kidney) and complex medical conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vitamin E consumption and/or supplementation on breast cancer risk, treatment, and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between vitamin E consumption and breast cancer risk, nor any impact of supplementation on risk. However, vitamin E consumption was inversely associated with breast cancer recurrence, though no association was found for mortality.
population_specificity: Individuals studied in relation to breast cancer risk, recurrence, and outcomes (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether vitamin E could effectively treat chronic insomnia in postmenopausal women as an alternative to sedative drugs and hormonal therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in baseline characteristics between groups, but the vitamin E group had a slightly higher median PSQI score at baseline. The abstract does not report final efficacy outcomes, so the impact of vitamin E on sleep quality or sedative drug use remains unclear.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with chronic insomnia disorder (n=160).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic role of Vitamin E in cancer management by reviewing recent randomized control trials.
results_summary: The study found heterogeneous results across sixteen RCTs, with some suggesting potential detriment from Vitamin E supplementation and no clear consensus on its effectiveness in cancer therapeutics. The need for well-designed, large, prospective RCTs was emphasized.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (specific type not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of tocotrienol (T3), a member of the vitamin E family, for managing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by reviewing clinical and preclinical studies.
results_summary: T3 supplementation improved NAFLD outcomes, including liver histology, ultrasound results, and liver profiles, by enhancing lipid metabolism, reducing liver steatosis, and mitigating inflammation and fibrosis. The effectiveness varied based on NAFLD severity, study duration, and the type of T3 intervention (isomers or mixtures).
population_specificity: Nondiabetic steatohepatitis patients (human studies) and animal models (preclinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of vitamin E in addressing thermal burn injuries, infections, and sepsis.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation, whether enteral or parenteral, was found to prevent, mitigate, and even reverse the effects of thermal burn injuries, infections, and sepsis. The study suggests a need for large-scale prospective observational studies to confirm these benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with thermal burn injuries, infections, and sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of vitamin E in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation was found to be effective in reducing joint discomfort, edema, and stiffness in RA patients, with potential benefits linked to restoring the intestinal barrier and improving gastrointestinal health.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients (39,845 participants across nine studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary vitamin E supplementation on exercise-induced muscle damage, oxidative stress, and inflammation in randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation, particularly below 500 IU, showed a protective effect on muscle damage (measured by creatine kinase and lactate dehydrogenase), with greater benefits observed in athletes and when CK was measured immediately after exercise.
population_specificity: Athletes and subjects in randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of tocotrienols (a form of Vitamin E) in cancer, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory mechanisms, as well as their bioavailability enhancement strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights tocotrienols' systemic intracellular anti-cancer, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects, with ongoing human trials supporting their safety at low doses and potential in diverse clinical diseases. Recent advancements focus on improving bioavailability through targeted drug delivery methods.
population_specificity: Animal models, in vitro assays, and ongoing human trials (specific population not detailed).
effective_dosage: Low doses (specific amount and frequency not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the known roles of vitamin E supplementation in women for gynaecological health and reproductive-related diseases and provide future perspectives.
results_summary: The abstract highlights vitamin E's importance in reproductive processes and its antioxidant properties, but notes that its effects on female fertility and gynaecological health are poorly understood and lacking.
population_specificity: Women, particularly in the context of reproductive health and gynaecological diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Vitamin E and Omega 3 supplementation on reproductive indices, particularly sperm parameters and sex hormones, among workers exposed to electromagnetic fields.
results_summary: The study found that simultaneous consumption of Vitamin E and Omega 3 significantly improved sperm morphology and motility. Exposure to electric fields negatively affected sperm count, morphology, and motility.
population_specificity: Workers in an automobile parts manufacturing plant exposed to low-frequency electromagnetic fields.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin E supplementation could ameliorate symptoms of depression and anxiety by evaluating its anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed a modest but inconclusive benefit of Vitamin E for depression (SMD: -0.88) and anxiety (SMD: -0.86), with high heterogeneity. Most studies had low risk of bias, but results were mixed due to varying study designs and inclusion of other constituents like omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Participants with depression and/or anxiety (354 for depression, 306 for anxiety meta-analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of alpha-tocopherol (vitamin E) supplementation on ApoA1 and ApoB levels, which are predictors of cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of vitamin E supplementation on ApoA1 or ApoB levels in adults, with no clinically meaningful changes observed.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25.4 to 59 years (1,284 participants across seven studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of tocotrienol-rich vitamin E (Tocovid Suprabio) on diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) and neuropathic pain.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that tocotrienols exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties, but specific outcomes regarding pain reduction or quality of life improvements are not detailed.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with peripheral neuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vitamin E supplementation on endothelial dysfunction, inflammation, and oxidative stress biomarkers in adult hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation significantly decreased intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1), indicating potential benefits for reducing inflammation and oxidative stress in hemodialysis patients. The meta-analysis included 11 trials with 491 patients, showing statistically significant effects.
population_specificity: Adult patients receiving hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Vitamin E on growth performance and flesh quality in sub-adult grass carp, focusing on molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Dietary Vitamin E improved growth performance, flesh quality, and fatty acid synthesis in grass carp, while reducing fatty acid decomposition and endoplasmic reticulum stress. Optimal dosages enhanced muscle protein, lipid content, and texture.
population_specificity: Sub-adult grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella), initial weight 713.53 ± 1.50 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Vitamin E supplementation on cardiometabolic risk factors, inflammatory and oxidative markers, and hormonal functions in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation improved lipid profile, reduced insulin and HOMA-IR levels, decreased LH and testosterone concentrations, and increased FSH and progesterone levels. It also significantly improved triglyceride (TG), LDL levels, waist circumference (WC), and HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral synthetic vitamin E (400 IU/day) for eight weeks improved semen parameters and pregnancy rates in men with idiopathic abnormal sperm motility and/or morphology.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in sperm volume, count, motility, or morphology between the vitamin E and placebo groups after eight weeks. Interestingly, the placebo group showed a significant decrease in the percentage of normal sperm, while vitamin E supplementation may have helped prevent further oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Infertile couples with male factor infertility (idiopathic abnormal sperm motility and/or morphology) admitted to an IVF program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of α-tocopherol supplementation on lipid parameters in diabetes mellitus (DM) patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of α-tocopherol supplementation on lipid profiles in DM patients, except when used for ≥12 weeks. The overall conclusion was that α-tocopherol had no meaningful impact on lipid parameters.
population_specificity: Diabetes mellitus (DM) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current knowledge on Vitamin E supplementation in neurodegenerative diseases and explore its potential for individualized neuro-nutrition.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results regarding Vitamin E's benefits in neurodegenerative disorders, with some trials showing no substantiated effects and others reporting adverse effects like increased amyloid β synthesis in Alzheimer's disease. Genetic and nutritional factors may influence its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's or Parkinson's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin E supplementation could effectively prevent chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) in patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Vitamin E supplementation at 600 mg/day reduced the incidence of CIPN, particularly in cisplatin-treated patients, and improved neurotoxicity scores and reflex outcomes compared to placebo. However, benefits were not sustained after six rounds of chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemotherapy, specifically those at risk for CIPN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential effects and mechanisms of vitamin E on neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, stroke, and ALS.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that vitamin E may have protective effects against neurodegeneration by mitigating oxidative stress and suppressing genes linked to neurodegeneration, though the exact mechanisms remain unclear.
